item.title: R Classes: factor vs. character
item.description:
How to subset a data frame with only gene names in common with another list? Turned out, problem was the class of one list was a 'factor' and the other was a 'character'.

> qPCR<-read.csv("file1.csv") > Affy_DE_list<-read.csv("file2.csv") > class(qPCR) [1] "data.frame" > class …

item.title: Draft Genome Annotation
item.description: Annotating a draft de novo genome assembly of a previously-uncharacterized species with gene function information is a challenging problem. Genome->transcriptome->protein sequence information is collected experimentally and …

item.title: Useful Linux commands
item.description:
Decompress a gzipped tar file:
tar -xzvf file.tar.gz
Or just a tar file:
tar -xvf file.tar
Install program:
tar -xzvf rsem-1.2.8.tar.gz cd rsem-1.2.8 make cd EBSeq make echo 'export PATH=$PATH:/root/rsem-1.2.8' >> ~/.bashrc source ~/.bashrc
Screen command, when …

item.title: Workshop on Genomics (Notes) - Intro Lab Setup
item.description:
"Cloud" computing, essentially storage services (Hotmail, Gmail, flickr, iTunes, Netflix, Dropbox, etc.).

Article on 'Wired' about Google infrastructure. Data centers located all over world, water cooling required.

item.title: Simulations with Random Numbers
item.description:
Randomly-generated numbers by a computer are not actually random. They are programmed to seem random. This is technically considered pseudorandom. To repeatedly use the same set of randomly-generated numbers in R, use the set.seed(1) function.

https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/compdata/slides%2Fsimulation.pdf
